docs.lead_paragraph: The life-threatening stroke that Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon suffered early this month has focused attention on the treatment of strokes, in particular the use of anticoagulants and clot-dissolving drugs. The use of such drugs is among the most potentially dangerous therapies in medicine and one of the most controversial. The full story of Mr. Sharon's case is not known because his family and doctors have released limited information. But questions have been raised about whether the drugs he received for a less severe stroke in December, caused by a blood clot, may have contributed to his huge stroke on Jan. 4.

headline.main: As in Sharon's Case, Handling Of Stroke Has Many Variables

docs.abstract: Therapies used to manage and minimize effects of strokes have wide variety of potential benefits and risks; studies show that identifying type of stroke early aids in administration of appropriate drug therapies, but does not necessarily identify best treatment; differences between ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes described; former Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon's life-threatening stroke and course of treatment, which involved anticoagulants, discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The life-threatening stroke that Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon suffered early this month has focused attention on the treatment of strokes, in particular the use of anticoagulants and clot-dissolving drugs.      The use of such drugs is among...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I pleaded with my sister, Susan, to get genetic testing, but she refused,'' a woman recently told me in my office. Susan, the woman said, already had breast cancer, so her health insurance company would have paid for the testing.

headline.main: Genetic Testing Creates New Versions of Ancient Dilemmas

docs.abstract: Dr Robert Klitzman Cases column discusses difficult medical decisions associated with learning results of genetic tests; holds that genetic test results can be misleading and do not always provide definitive link to developing disease; compares understanding test results to ancient Greeks interpreting oracles of future; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: In the new genetic age, the notion that family members are "bound by ties of blood" takes on new meaning.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two months ago, when her surgeon recommended a series of treatments that would pump drugs directly into her abdominal cavity to fight advanced ovarian cancer, Gail Hilvers called her chemotherapy doctor to request it. He flatly refused. ''He said no research showed it was effective,'' said Ms. Hilvers, who is 51.

headline.main: A Therapy Fell Out of Favor, But Didn't Stop Saving Lives

docs.abstract: Intraperitoneal therapy, or IP, has been given limited use as aggressive treatment in fight against ovarian cancer; National Cancer Institute, in reaction to recent studies and reported success of IP, is now encouraging doctors to offer treatment to all women who fit medical criteria for it; IP can have serious side effects and is much more difficult to administer than traditional chemotherapy treatments, but studies show its use produces largest survival increase in any gynecologic cancer; treatment described; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: About 8 percent of travelers to developing countries require medical care during or after travel, according to a new study of more than 17,000 people who became ill while traveling from 1996 to 2004. Overall, the most common ailment was acute diarrhea, but among travelers to Africa, it was malaria.

headline.main: Travelers' Illnesses: The Souvenirs Nobody Wants

docs.abstract: GeoSentinel Clinics publishes research in New England Journal of Medicine that identifies most common illnesses contracted by travelers in developing countries; finds that eight percent of travelers to developing countries require medical attention during or after trip; map; graph (M)
docs.snippet: About 8 percent of travelers to developing countries require medical care during or after travel, according to a new study of more than 17,000 people who became ill while traveling from 1996 to 2004.     Overall, the most common ailment was acute...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ariel Sharon, Israel's prime minister; Randal McCloy Jr., a West Virginia miner; and Rubén Contreras, a Mexican boxer, received the same treatment after a brain injury: each was put into a medically induced coma. But although it is widely used, the treatment remains controversial, and little beyond anecdotal evidence supports its effectiveness.

headline.main: Evidence Sparse for Using Induced Coma as Therapy

docs.abstract: Medically induced coma, which is widely used treatment for brain injury, remains controversial as there is no concrete evidence of its effectiveness; Dr Stephan A Mayer, Columbia University Medical Center (NYC) neurological intensive care unit director, holds that medical coma should be last-ditch approach after more conventional procedures fail; possible complications of medically induced coma described (M)
docs.snippet: Ariel Sharon, Israel's prime minister; Randal McCloy Jr., a West Virginia miner; and Rubén Contreras, a Mexican boxer, received the same treatment after a brain injury: each was put into a medically induced coma.     But although it is widely used,...

docs.lead_paragraph: There's no question that the amount of lead in children's blood has dropped significantly in recent decades, much to the benefit of their brains and bodies. There's also no question that children who are still being permanently damaged by excessive lead levels live mainly at the poverty level or near it, in neighborhoods where they can be poisoned by lead from contaminated paint, water, soil and dust. However, no one at any level of society, not even those with seven-figure incomes, can afford to be complacent about the exposure of children to lead in home and play environments.

headline.main: Dally No Longer: Get the Lead Out

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column describes sources of lead poisoning and discusses ways to minimize health risk, particularly for children; calls for tighter regulations and better testing for lead exposure; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: There's no question that the amount of lead in children's blood has dropped significantly in recent decades, much to the benefit of their brains and bodies. There's also no question that children who are still being permanently damaged by excessive...

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans have drunk alcohol on the job or before going to work, a new study suggests. Much has been written about how alcohol use and abuse affect work performance through absenteeism and other problems. This study, in the current Journal of Studies on Alcohol, set out instead to look at the extent of alcohol use and impairment. The researchers, led by Michael R. Frone of the Research Institute on Addictions at the State University of New York at Buffalo, surveyed 2,800 adults in 48 states, asking how often they drank alcohol within two hours of reporting to work, how often they drank it on the job and how often they worked feeling the effects of alcohol or having a hangover.

headline.main: Cocktails on a Coffee Break? You're Not Alone

docs.abstract: Dr Michael R Frone of Research Institute on Addictions at State University of New York, Buffalo, leads study that finds 15 percent of people surveyed reported that they had either drank alcohol on job or within two hours of going to work; research is published in Journal of Studies on Alcohol; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM Keeping a wallet in your back pocket can cause sciatica. THE FACTS -- A wallet stuffed with business cards or scraps of paper might seem like more of an eyesore than a health hazard. But one old bromide holds that a thick wallet -- or even one that's not so thick -- can harm the lower back for those sit on it for too long. And while experts says the fears are probably exaggerated, the wallet can definitely carry some hazards.
docs.abstract: Research shows that keeping thick wallet in back pants pocket can lead to developing sciatica; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sport utility vehicles may seem indomitable as they plow along, but despite their bulk, children who ride in them are no better protected than those riding in ordinary cars, a new study finds. Writing in the current issue of Pediatrics, researchers say they have found little difference in injuries when looking at crashes involving passenger cars and S.U.V.'s, which on average weigh 1,317 pounds more. The lead author of the study was Dr. Lauren Daly of the Alfred I. duPont Hospital for Children in Wilmington, Del.

headline.main: In S.U.V., Children Aren't Necessarily Safer

docs.abstract: Dr Lauren Daly of Alfred I duPont Hospital for Children leads study that finds that child riding in Sport Utility Vehicle is not any better protected from harm caused by accident than child riding in regular car; cites that rollover rate in SUV is twice that of ordinary car; research is published in journal Pediatrics; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Sport utility vehicles may seem indomitable as they plow along, but despite their bulk, children who ride in them are no better protected than those riding in ordinary cars, a new study finds.     Writing in the current issue of Pediatrics,...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the small world of people who train dogs to sniff cancer, a little-known Northern California clinic has made a big claim: that it has trained five dogs -- three Labradors and two Portuguese water dogs -- to detect lung cancer in the breath of cancer sufferers with 99 percent accuracy. The study was based on well-established concepts. It has been known since the 80's that tumors exude tiny amounts of alkanes and benzene derivatives not found in healthy tissue.

headline.main: Dogs Excel on Smell Test to Find Cancer

docs.abstract: Michael McCulloch, Pine Street Foundation research director, leads study on ability of trained dogs to detect individuals with cancer by their smell; research, which is published in Integrative Cancer Therapies, finds that trained dogs are 99 percent accurate in detecting lung cancer; suggests that dogs could be used as preliminary screening for cancer; photo (M)
